quote: Please, take the tricorder. I am unable to sufficiently pinpoint your location to be able to hand it to you.
You're blind.
Yes, sir.
(handing the tricorder to Worf) Destroy this.
But, sir, it contains the record of all that we have discovered here.
And that is precisely why it must be destroyed. Time?
Three minutes.
I am running out of time. We all are.
This room and the technology contained in it must be destroyed. It cannot be allowed to fall into Romulan hands.
I understand...
How! How do I do it? How can I destroy everything? Control room, the probes? All of it.
The... power... source.
I detonate it?
Yes.
How? What do I do?
The... probes.
Probes... the probes. Launch? Do I launch the probes?
What's that going to do? Nothing.
Doors.
Doors?
Perhaps the probes are in a launch bay.
The doors will open automatically when the launch begins. I'd have to override.
Yes.
The power source! The backwash from the rockets will spill into the main power grids and cause an overload.
Cor... rect.
Which control keys? Damn, I forgot you can't see.
Help.
Describe.
We're directly opposite the gateway. There is a rectangular screen.
Left... one meter.
Triangular screen. The lights directly above are solid amber. To the left red --
Cor... rect. Key... blue, amber... amber... red.
That's the launch sequence?
How do I override the doors?
Blue, blue, blue.

I hope you're not stuttering. I don't know how long a delay there will be between the launch and the detonation. I'll hold off keying the launch sequence until you're through the gate. How long until the Enterprise returns?
Almost time, sir. Captain, you will be killed.
I'll go through the gate.
But where will you end up?
Any place is going to be better than this room. Worf, I'm depending on you. Get Data back to the Enterprise. He may be their last hope.
Worf! What happened? Where's the captain?
We must take Data to Engineering.
I don't know how to help him. But comparing recorded norms for Data to the current readings, it's clear that all his functions are going crazy. If we had an expert -- Maddox, or somebody --
He's gone.
Kandar se. Kandar ere.
Data!
What the hell?
Ah, I have access.
The self-correcting mechanism --
Captain? Captain?
It's constantly kicking in to make minute adjustments in the positronic brain.
This is the Enterprise. How did I get here?
He cleared the Iconian program from his own system. How?
Iconia? I was on Iconia. Now I am on the Enterprise.
Geordi, this is critical. How?

Let me think for a second. There was an incompatible program running through Data's system, so the mechanism started searching for a way to keep him alive. The solution must have been a shutdown and a total wipe of all affected memory.
Query. What have I forgotten?
One question. Can we do the same thing with the Enterprise?

I don't see why not... but it will have to be a complete shutdown. We turn her off, effect a wipe of the Yamato log and every subsequent event since we downloaded it. I'll then reload all the ship's programs from the protected archives in the main core.
Geordi, a shutdown means that the shields are going to be coming down too, and we're hanging nose to nose with a Romulan battle cruiser.
Hey, Commander, whether it's Romulan phasers or our own warp engines we're just as dead.
Make it so.
Can I help?
Kandar more, kandar sete, kandar ne.
All systems functioning.
Lock on the captain and bring him back.
Scanning, sir. Got him.
Kandar qetar, Kandar jet, kandar piqe, kandar...
Setha-tri par trukatha.
I've lost him!
Damn it!
Got him! Sir! He's on the Romulan ship.
How the hell... never mind. Energize!
You did this.
Setha-ki par trukatha.
Did what?
Activated the auto-destruct. I at least have the satisfaction that you will die with us.
Setha-mille par trukatha.
(feeling the effects of the transporter kicking in) Not I think, today, Commander.
Bridge.
Yes, sir.
Get us out of here. The Romulan ship is set for auto-destruct and they can't deactivate it.
Wait, sir. Open a hailing frequency.
Open, sir.
Commander Taris, prepare to receive a transmission from our chief engineer. He'll instruct you on how to purge your system.
Commander, your transmission has been received and acknowledged.
Now, Mister Data, warp speed please -- just in case Taris's engineer is not as efficient as Lieutenant La Forge.
Yes, sir. Captain, sensors picking up a large explosion on the surface of Iconia. It is equivalent to a force twelve hydrogen explosion. Blast radius is nine hundred kilometers.

The dust particles entering the stratosphere will take an estimated seven months to fall back to the surface. The diminution in sunlight will have the effect of lowering average daily surface temperatures on Iconia by fifteen degrees Celsius.
I see Data's back to normal.
With a little touch of amnesia.
It seems that everything is back to normal. Well done, Commander.
Thank you, sir.
All hands, this is the captain. The sun in the Delos system is undergoing large-scale magnetic field changes, producing violent, gigantic flares.
We will be studying this star at close range. Even though we will be running with full deflectors, the closeness of the event and its severity are going to create problems.

Intense magnetic fields have a disruptive effect on electrical systems. We can therefore expect an interruption of communications, and potential temporary loss of other systems. As a precaution, we are now going to Yellow Alert...
Stay sharp, everyone.
Engineering, this is Ops. Bring all systems on line and direct full power to the shields.
All sections secure.
Lieutenant La Forge?
Course set.
Half impulse.
Half impulse, aye.
On Main Viewer.
Mask out the photosphere.
Magnify. Quadrant one-seven, sector four-zero-three.
I've never seen anything like this before. The violence of these eruptions is awesome.
And humbling, Number One.
Reading an unusual number of sunspots and eruptive prominences, sir. The magnetic field is extremely irregular.
Captain, deflectors are being hit by a huge burst of X-rays.
Wow -- look! Sir, my console seems to be overloading.
The X-ray burst is disrupting systems, Captain. I'm adjusting deflectors to compensate.
Increase power to forward deflectors.
Status report.
All systems operational, sir.
Captain. The level of tension on the ship is mounting.
Understandable. Data?
If we are to investigate this unusual solar activity -- we must get closer.
Mister La Forge, move us closer.
We'll be pushing our deflectors to the limit, but we'll get a good look at this phenomenon.
Captain, I have intercepted what seems to be a distress signal.
Let me hear it.
This... -- this is ... -- on the freighter Sanction... ... and unable to... .... Need help.
The transmission is from a freighter in orbit around the fourth planet of the system. However, the receiving station is on the third planet.
Open hailing frequency.
Hailing frequencies open.
Unidentified freighter, this is the USS Enterprise. May we be of assistance?
Whoever you are, YES! .... cannot maintain... ... if you can help...
Can't you enhance the image?
Too much interference.
Set a course to intersect with the freighter. Warp two.
Aye, sir.
Maintain Yellow Alert.
Can't control... ... ship is losing orbit... ... heading into atmosphere... without help, we'll burn up.
It is a freighter -- very old.
Captain, our sensors are being severely affected by the sun flares.
Helm -- get us in as close as possible to the freighter's orbit.
Aye, sir.
There are six life forms aboard the freighter.
Captain, the freighter's orbit is decaying.
How long until it loses integrity?
A matter of minutes.
(he touches his arm-panel) Unidentified freighter, this is the USS Enterprise.
Enterprise, this is the Aurelian freighter... Sanction.
Put this on the Main Viewer.
The visual transmission is still breaking up.
Freighter, this is the Enterprise. What is your situation?
Get us off here.
Please -- help us.
This is the Enterprise -- with all this interference it is difficult to copy your transmission -- if you all talk at once... it is impossible. Now -- please -- say again. What is your situation?
I am T'Jon -- the captain of the Sanction.
At last. How can we help?

We have lost -- I don't know... something -- and I am no longer able to maintain this orbit, nor am I able to use main thrusters. Everything's just kind of... you know... dead, I guess. It's all... you know... shut down.
That's very vague. What's the computer analysis?
The computer's not working very well.
Data... can you tap into their computer and clarify the situation?
I will attempt it.
Captain, the tractor beam is available, if you want it.
At least we can pull them out of orbit before they enter the atmosphere.
Yes. Captain T'Jon -- we are going to lock on our tractor beam and pull you out of orbit.
Hey -- that's great.
The solar flares are interfering with the tractor beam, Captain. I am unable to lock on.
Captain, the freighter's orbit continues to deteriorate.
Captain T'Jon, we are unable to attach our tractor beam because of the intense solar activity.
I understand. Thanks for trying.
Captain, I have determined what is malfunctioning on the freighter.
Enterprise to Sanction. We have analyzed your problem.
Great.
Your ship's design uses an electromagnetic coil to constrict the exhaust flow. That coil is misaligned.
Have you the necessary tools to realign the coil?
I don't think so.
Captain, I believe we can provide the freighter with a temporary substitute. Ship's stores contain a coil of the proper type.
Can we beam it over?
Yes.
Captain T'Jon, we will beam over a replacement coil.
That's great... and that will fix us up?
Well, once it's installed.
Right. ... And how do we do that?
What's the matter with these people? How can he be the captain of the vessel and be ignorant of its simplest functions?
If this weren't so serious it would make you laugh.
Captain T'Jon -- how long have you been in command of the freighter?
Seven years. This is my twenty-sixth voyage to Brekka.
And you don't know how to align a control coil?
It's never come up.
Is there anyone on board who can do it?
Hold on a minute... I'll ask.
Sorry -- nobody here knows anything about it.
I'll beam over with a team.
Captain -- I strongly recommend against anyone from this ship beaming over. The solar interference is too great.
The freighter has entered the planet's atmosphere. Disintegration is imminent.
We are running out of options.
(nods to Tasha and Riker) Let's get them off there.
Captain T'Jon. Prepare to beam over.
If you think that's best.
Unless you have another option -- yes, I "think that's best."
Whatever you say.
I can't maintain a positive lock.
An unusual E-M burst. Readings off scale.
Freighter Sanction, this is the Enterprise. We are having difficulty getting a fix.
Have them go to their own Transporter Room. It will be tricky, but perhaps I can link the two transporters in series and get them over with the increased power.
It's worth a try. Captain T'Jon -- go immediately to your Transporter Room. Contact me from there.
Right, Enterprise -- we'll call you from there... but, if you can't get us with your transporter, what makes you think ours will do the job?
I'm going to interconnect them.
I didn't know you could do that.
Hurry -- we're running out of time.
We're on the way.
I don't think they're going to make it.
Captain T'Jon doesn't seem to care one way or the other.
Worf -- how much time do we have?
One minute, twenty-eight seconds.
Captain T'Jon -- are you there?
Yeah. We're in the transporter room.
Great. Activate your transporter. Set coordinates nine -- seven -- zero -- three... mark two... six... eight.
Did you say... two -- eight -- six... or eight -- eight -- six.
(frustrated almost to the point of anger) TWO -- SIX -- EIGHT.
Got it.
The hull temperature of the freighter is passing three thousand degrees.
What's the holdup, Number One?
We are establishing the link now.
We are ready.
Then all six of you get on the transporter platform -- on my signal, energize.
I've got their initial transporter signal. Interlock complete. Energize on my mark. Four -- three -- two -- one -- energize.
Did you get them off?
No. They stayed on the freighter -- and sent their cargo.
Cargo!? Are those people crazy? What could possibly be that important?
Sir -- the freighter is disintegrating.
Captain, the freighter is entering the atmosphere. Her hull temperature is building.
Number One -- I don't understand these people. Their lives are in danger and they're sending over cargo?
Unbelievable.
We're losing the freighter. You've got to beam those people over now.
Clear that cargo. Beam it to a hold.
Aye, sir.
Freighter Sanction... this is the Enterprise, get on the transporter pad and... Forget it. Just lock on to any life forms you can find and get them over.
Trying, sir.
The freighter is going down.
Transporter Room! You're out of time.
Reading six life forms... But I can't get a solid lock.
We've no choice. Energize.
You said SIX - where are... ... the other two?
The lock didn't hold, sir.
Re-establish.
It's too late.
Number One!?
scene: 37A  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: Two are lost, sir. But we saved four.
I am Commander William Riker of the USS Enterprise. I'm sorry. We were unable to rescue the other two.
Were they with you... (then indicating the other pair) ... or with you?
With us.
We did everything we could, if you had come instead of the cargo, you could have all made it.
The cargo... Where is it?
You did save it, didn't you?
Yes, we did. It's in one of our cargo holds. You act like it's more important than your comrades.
May we see it?
Thank you. It's just we thought we had lost it.
Careful with your choice of words, T'Jon. It's ours, not yours.
We paid a fair price for it!
You offered a fair price, but we have not received it.
You accepted our goods in trade!
Then where are they? Tell me!
That's not our problem!
No more than the barrel is your property. It's as simple as this. The goods were never delivered; they were destroyed with your ship.
Hence the deal was incomplete; hence possession of the Felicium remains ours!
We need it.
Commander, I request you transport my associate -- -- and myself down to our planet, with our merchandise.
Yes, get them out of here! But the barrel stays.
There's no reasoning with you.
Langor, you expect too much from them. You always have and you are always disappointed. (then to T'Jon with a hard edge) You didn't pay -- so it's not yours.
Damn you, Sobi --
Stop this! Now!
Security to Cargo Bay Eleven!
Behave yourselves, Gentlemen.
Escort our "visitors" to the Observation Lounge.
A natural electrical charge... ?
Formidable.
Yes, and a difficult weapon to confiscate.
We have to resolve this. There isn't much time.
What can you offer?
Everything we had went down with the Sanction.
Then it is going to be difficult to accommodate you.
Solar flares are increasing in magnitude, sir. Deflectors are shaky, but holding.
Maintain. And our rather combative guests, Number One?
Waiting for you in the Observation Lounge, sir.
Data, what can you tell me about the inhabitants of this system?

Not very much, sir. The only recorded contact with the Delos system was over two hundred years ago. A scout ship reported two inhabited planets, both technologically just on the edge of acquiring space travel.
Odd that in two centuries, neither civilization advanced further.
Sir, I find it strange that none of our visitors feel much remorse about the two freighter passengers who perished... yet their barrel of cargo is a source of great anxiety to them.
Yes, let us pay a call and get some answers. Counselor, Number One, Mister Data...
Captain, may I present Sobi and Langor from the planet Brekka, which we are now orbiting. And T'Jon and Romas... from the neighboring planet, Ornara.
I am sorry we could not save your ship.
You could have repaired it.
Yes.
We have only two left. Neither works. They are critical to our survival. Could you fix them?
Mister Data?
Our computer downloaded the specifications for the magnetic coils the freighters depend on, sir. Assuming the malfunction is similar... suitable replacements can be fabricated.
Instruct Engineering to proceed.
Aye, sir.
Now, as for our cargo...
Our cargo, Captain.
Wrong, Sobi --
My first officer has said ownership of the cargo is in dispute. This is a question which must be settled by whatever legal mechanisms exist between your societies.
Captain Picard, you don't understand. This is a matter of life and death.
Why is that? What is the cargo?
Medicine.
Indeed.
Our home planet is in desperate need, Captain. Ornara suffers from a lethal plague.
The cargo you have impounded represents the only hope of life for our people.
Is that right?
Yes.
You must think us heartless brutes, Captain, but look at our side of it. The plant which yields the medicine Felicium grows only in remote areas of our home planet Brekka.
It must be painstakingly cultivated, harvested, and purified... a complex and expensive process.
That single shipment of Felicium represents an enormous investment. We can't just give it away!
We paid for it. We are asking only for what is ours.
That is your viewpoint. Ours, of course, differs.
You are going to hold to that position.
I am constrained to abide by the terms of our agreement.
Then you condemn us to death!
Romas --
You disgust me! If you saw the suffering the plague has brought, would you still be so heartless?
We are going to get to find out, when you see what the plague does to us.
Romas -- you and T'Jon carry the disease?
Yes. Every Ornaran does.
Then you may have brought it aboard my ship! Was there a medical scan during transport?
Unverified -- the solar flares may have caused a malfunction in the biofilters --
Red Alert! Medical emergency -- decks twelve and thirteen. Doctor Crusher to the Observation Lounge immediately!
You find us well, I trust?
As far as I can tell. Your physiology is somewhat different but I detect no dangerous virus or bacteria.
I assure you we are in perfect health.
We're not! We need our medicine.
Our medicine.
We paid for it -- it's ours now!
Enough!
Of course you are right, Doctor. Could we leave now?
I see no reason why not. Escort them to their quarters.
Captain, could I talk with you please... in private.
Not right now.
What have you learned?
The Brekkians are free of infection. The Ornarans have all the symptoms of a disease -- but I can't find a cause.
Perhaps the transporter filtered it out when they were beamed aboard?
There's no record of it. Then again, the solar flare activity may have caused a transporter malfunction.
Are they going to die?
The physiology is somewhat different from ours, so I need to check further, but... my instinct says no.
Do you think we are in danger from this plague?
Again, I don't think so, but I need more time to know for sure.
There are some missing pieces to the puzzle, don't you feel that too?
What's missing here is a little humanity.
Are we losing our professional detachment, Doctor?
Perhaps. As Captain, I think you should know that I am developing a very active dislike of the Brekkians.
Understandable.
Captain, you must give us back our cargo.
I can't do that.
Why not? It belongs to us.
And the Brekkians insist it is theirs.
They lie!
Maybe so, but it's not for me to decide.
We need some now... NOW! I don't care if it's your 'decision' or not... get us some!
Captain, what's happening to us, is happening to thousands more on Ornara. Please understand the magnitude of the problem.
Your people don't need it -- (indicating the Brekkians) -- they don't need it... our people do!
If you don't give it to us, you will be party to murder... not only us, but an entire civilization!
Sorry, I did not mean to insult you. I'm feeling very shaky.
We cannot hold out much longer!
No, Captain -- I think they should have it. They believe it will help them. That in itself might control their symptoms.
I'll talk with the Brekkians.
Thank you, Captain. I appreciate anything you can do.
May I say, Captain, how impressed we are with your ship and its facilities.
Thank you.
And its crew. Everyone is so efficient and professional.
I am glad you are comfortable. I've come to seek your agreement to an Ornaran request.
We cannot --
Wait. Let the Captain speak. We want to be reasonable.
The Ornarans are quite ill and are insistent that they need Felicium.
That is not surprising.
Then would you object to allowing them enough Felicium for their immediate needs?
Captain, we Brekkians are in business -- we are not in the habit of giving away what has not been paid for.
You would let them die rather than share the medicine?
We want to be fair, Captain. We agree to permitting them two dosages for immediate use.
No charge.
I'll have our medical officer handle it.
I trust you won't mind if we are present while you open the cargo, Captain.
Point-zero-one milliliters is the proper individual dosage.
A very potent substance.
We've perfected our distillation process over the years. In my grandfather's day, the same amount of Felicium would have filled five rooms this size, Captain.
No doubt you have applied your technology from other industries to the refinement of this product.
We have no other industry.
None at all?
We don't need any. The Ornarans provide us everything we need -- in exchange for this.
Fascinating. Your society dedicated exclusively to the production of a single product.
A product for which you have no use for, but which the Ornarans can't live without.
One of the little ironies of life, Captain.
But one we'd be fools not to take advantage of. It is mutually beneficial.
The Ornarans provide us with the necessities of life and we provide them with the necessities of living. It is a fair exchange.
A most interesting relationship.
Excuse me... I'll take this to Sickbay.
Can I help?
No.
Hurry up!
You are feeling better?
Yes. Thank you. I'm fine now.
Report, Doctor Crusher.
I may not know Felicium's full effect on Ornaran physiology. But I know how to interpret physical reactions.
Are the Ornarans recovering?
Both T'Jon and Romas are fine... in fact, too fine. Felicium is a narcotic.
Then T'Jon, Romas -- indeed every Ornaran --
-- is a drug addict.
It's a fascinating little tale we've run into of disease -- rescue -- commerce -- and interdependence between two worlds.
You have piqued my interest, Number One -- please continue.
Mister Data.

Beginning several thousand years ago, the two worlds took different paths. Ornara became technically sophisticated, Brekka did not. Then two hundred years ago Ornara was stricken by a devastating plague.
Their advanced technology could offer no solution.
Somehow, and there is limited information on this point, the cure was found in a plant which is indigenous to only Brekka, and which resisted all attempts at cultivation on Ornara.
In any case a trading situation quickly developed, which still exists.
The Ornarans acquire the Felicium from the Brekkians, and in exchange, the Ornarans provide the Brekkians with foods and staples.
A nice arrangement for the Brekkians.
And for the Ornarans -- without the medicine they would all die.

No they wouldn't. Captain, here are the results of my analysis. Felicium is definitely a powerful and addictive narcotic. What's more, despite what the Ornarans have been saying, it's not a medicine. It was a medicine, and it did cure the plague, two hundred years ago.
And they no longer need it.
The plague is irrelevant now: it doesn't exist... and it's not going to recur.
The Ornarans have no medical need for Felicium.
No, but their physical and psychological need is very real.
What are you going to do?
Based on what we know so far... there is nothing I can do.
And you don't think drug addiction and exploitation is sufficient cause?
This situation has existed for a very long time. Those two societies are intertwined in a symbiotic relationship.
With one society profiting at the expense of the other.
That's how you see it.
I can synthesize a non-addictive substitute which will ease their withdrawal symptoms.
No. We can't do that either.
I know this. You can't let them have the Felicium.
Why? Because it goes against our moral sensibilities? Our mission is not to force Federation or Earth values on others in the galaxy.
In this case... you're wrong, Captain. One hundred percent wrong.
Captain, I am receiving a call from Ornara.
Patch it in here.
The signal's ragged, but I think I can put it on the Viewscreen.
I am Margan. Are my people on board your ship?
Some of them, yes.
May I speak with them?
Yes. Lieutenant Yar, have the Ornarans brought in... no, wait, I don't want them to have access to the bridge. We will contact you in a few minutes. I will take this in the guest quarters.
I can understand how this could happen to the Ornarans... What I can't understand is why anyone would voluntarily become dependent upon a chemical.
Yet, the voluntary addiction to drugs is a recurrent theme in many cultures.
As in the twenty-first century... when Earth governments used narcotics to control the military.
Or look at the twentieth century. The dangers of drug abuse were well known, yet their use was commonplace.
Why?
That is what I do not understand.
No one wants to become dependent. That happens later.
But it does happen. So why do people even start?
Oh, lots of reasons... My home planet was a place of great poverty and violence. For some, the only escape was through drugs.
I fail to comprehend how a chemical substance can provide an escape.
It doesn't. But it makes you think it does. You have to understand -- drugs can make you feel good.
They put you on top of the world. You're happy... Sure of yourself. In control. A lot of people never feel that otherwise.
But it is artificial.

It doesn't feel artificial. It feels natural, good, and mind expanding. Until the drug wears off. Then you pay the price. Once you come down, you're lower than when you started. So you take the drug again -- and it kicks you back up. But not as high this time.
So you take more.
But each peak gets lower and the valleys get deeper. Before you know it -- you're taking the drug not to feel good but to keep from feeling bad.
And that's the trap.
You think the drug expands your universe -- but it actually shrinks it. Shrinks it to where you and the drug are all that's left.
Pretty soon, all you care about is getting your next dosage. You'll lie, cheat, steal -- anything to get that fix.
Certainly by then you would realize the danger.
That's the worst of it. You don't care. The drug is your salvation -- your survival. Nothing else is important.
I guess I just don't understand.
Wesley, I hope you never do.
Lieutenant Yar, we are ready in the guest quarters.
T'Jon. Have you got it?
Well, it's here, but...
You've got to get it to us. T'Jon... please... We're dying here. You don't know... this is the worst it's ever been.
I'm doing everything I can. See... what happened was...
Stop. I can't listen. T'Jon... we need the medicine. So, many people... so much suffering. You've got to get it to us. I can't... I can't go on. Help, T'Jon... please.
I'm sorry.
Take us to our planet - leave us there with our medicine or this person dies.

Don't you see -- I have no choice. We were sent to bring back the Felicium. The suffering on my planet is too great. People are dying. It doesn't matter any more whether we are entitled to the Felicium... we have to have it.
Let him go.
Take us there now -- or give us a shuttle -- but we must have the medicine... if you refuse, this person dies.
I will not be coerced.
I'll do it. I'll kill him.
No you won't. You're not a killer and neither am I.
Help us... please... help us.
I'm not sure that I can.
Captain Picard, we couldn't help overhearing. Could I see you for a moment?
Come with me, Doctor. This could be interesting.
We have thought about this a great deal.
Both of us feel deeply about what is happening on Ornara.
Although this is going to cause hardship to us and to our people, we have decided to give the Felicium to them.
They can pay for it when they are able.
We don't want to cause any suffering.
I wonder why I expected this.
Pardon?
It's the other shoe.
The Ornarans are not aware, are they?
Of what?
That the plague which nearly destroyed Ornara... infected your world as well.
You don't know that for sure.
It had to.
But somehow, one of your ancestors realized that your desire for the drug continued after the disease had been cured. They made the connection and were able to end their addiction.
But these same wonderful people also realized that their neighbors never found out. Their need for the drug grew to the point it is now. Your sole source of support comes from providing the narcotic.
And the refinement process of which you are so proud was a way to make Felicium even more addicting... and tighten your grip on the Ornarans even further.
Are you going to tell them?

No. I can't tell them. You see, I am bound by the rules of the United Federation of Planets, which say I am not to interfere in other worlds, other cultures. To tell them any of this would be interfering and would violate the Prime Directive.
You're talking to us about it...
Telling you things you already know... which changes nothing.
Jean-Luc. I can synthesize something which will alleviate their suffering and make withdrawal painless.
That won't be necessary, because if I understand the captain, he is going to allow the Ornarans to have the Felicium.
Yes, I am.

You can't do that. Some things go beyond words on a page. These Brekkians have knowingly enslaved others. They have caused untold suffering and hardship, just so their pitiful lives could be easier. At least don't give the Ornarans more drugs.
It is not for me to make any of these decisions.
You are absolutely right, Captain.
Captain, we've arrived at Ornara and assumed standard orbit.
Acknowledged. Thank you.
Forgive me for doing what I must. I'm beaming you down to your world... with your Felicium.
Good. I knew it would work out this way.
You've made the only humanitarian decision, Captain.
Langor and I will beam down to Ornara with you.
We'll work out payment terms for the Felicium.
On behalf of my people, I extend thanks for your benevolent attitude.
And I also thank you, Captain, for doing the right thing.
Your gift of these coils will ensure that our freighters will continue to work.
No.
No.
I will not supply you with spare parts for your freighters. If you want them repaired, you'll have to do that yourself.
In a short time our freighters will be inoperable.
Quite possibly.
But we depend on those freighters! We must have those parts.
If you withhold those coils, you're disrupting the stability of both our planets --
-- and interfering with a trade arrangement that has lasted for generations! What of this Prime Directive of yours?
Nothing in the Prime Directive compels me to help you.
You're an executioner, Captain. You want our world to perish.
No. That's not what I want.
But without our freighters, there will be no more shipments of Felicium! We will die!
You must trust in yourselves. There are... other options.
And you must understand that my oath as a Starfleet officer gives me no choice in the matter.
Transporter Room. Lock onto our guests and their cargo and beam them down to Ornara.
Captain, I hope you realize what you've done to us.
Of that, you can be sure. Good luck.
When the Felicium runs out, the people of Ornara will suffer horrible withdrawal pains.
No doubt.
We could have made their burden easier.
Only in the short run. Painful as it will be, the people of Ornara -- and the people of Brekka -- must shape their own destinies.
It sounds so... heartless.
Doctor, it was not an easy decision.
I just hope it was the right one.
Mister La Forge, take us out of orbit.
Aye, sir. Course laid in.
Engage.
That's very nice.
No, it isn't. I just can't get it right. Do you think the wings are too big?
Not at all... birds have wings of all sizes, Eric. But you shouldn't worry about making it look perfect.
But Mrs. Narsu said we should try to make our sculptures as realistic as possible.
She's right... it is important for you to be able to give the clay the shape you want it to have.
But today you're not supposed to concentrate on technique. I'm here to help you focus more on the feelings you want to convey with your sculpture.
For instance... What do you think about when you see a bird?
Flying?
Fine. Then try to make your sculpture make me think of flying, too.
How's it going, Data?
I have finished.
The dimensions are accurate to within one-point-three percent.
I'm sure they are... You obviously have no trouble with realism, Data, but you're here to work on using your imagination. Maybe you should try something a little more... abstract.
I want you to start a new piece... I'd like you to sculpt... music.
Music?
Counselor. Music is a collection of acoustic vibrations. How can I reproduce a sound with clay?
Think of the effects that sounds have on people... the images that music brings to your mind... then give them a form.
(continuing, looks at the shape) It's a start.
Riker to Data... please report to the Bridge.
Acknowledged. I am on my way.

Captain's Log, Stardate 47615.2. We have encountered a rogue comet in sector one-one-five-six. It is not native to this region of space, and there is no previous record of this object on any Federation charts.
Based on its present trajectory, the comet appears to have originated in the D'Arsay system.
That's over two sectors from here...
That is correct, sir. This object has been en route for eighty-seven million years.
That's a long time alone in the dark.
Begin a full sensor analysis, Mister Data. Log the results for the Federation Astrophysical Survey.
Aye, sir.
The comet's outer shell is composed primarily of gaseous hydrogen and helium surrounding an icy mantle. The inner core consists of heavier elements--
What was that?
There is distortion within the comet's inner core. I believed we experienced an intense sensor echo.
Can you correct for it?
I am attempting to do so now, sir...
I've compensated for the effect. Sensors are reconfigured for a low intensity sweep.
We are still picking up some interference, but the distortion is manageable... At these settings, the scan will be complete in thirty-nine hours.
... Worf said he's going to be teaching us some Mok'bara throwing techniques today.
More like falling techniques... the last time we did that I was sore for a week...
What's this?
I have no idea.
Maybe Wil left it here... a little present?
It's not quite his style...
Then maybe you've got a secret admirer.
That's an interesting thought...
Well, you can figure it out later. We're going to be late.
We've been getting some pretty strange readings from that comet... now it looks like there's some kind of energy generation coming from the core.
Is that unusual?
The core is normally just a chunk of rock... it should be completely inert.
Maybe we've discovered a new kind of comet...
They must be changing the snacks around here.
I don't recognize it.
Well, whatever you do, don't put it in your mouth.
This is terrible.
I like it.
Then you can have it.. but it's not what I ordered.
Let's see what they're trying to poison you with...
Wait a minute... this stuff is bio-organic... there are oxygenated cells... serum electrolytes... This looks like some kind of... blood.
You're joking.
I'm serious.
I'm gonna have a little talk with the bartender.
It might not be his fault. We should check out the replicator.
Nice... Very good... I like that...
Data... This is amazing. How did you come up with this?
I followed your advice, Counselor. I used my imagination.
That's an understatement...
For some reason, as I shaped the clay, the image of the mask was exceptionally clear in my mind... the design seemed to flow quite... naturally.
Data, have you been in my quarters?
No, Counselor.
Somebody left an object in my room... it was some kind of artifact... and it looked similar to this. You don't know anything about that?
I do not.
Excuse me, Counselor, could you help me with my terminal? It's not working right.
Perhaps we should investigate this matter further.
These symbols don't match anything in Federation linguistic banks.
Some kind of alien information has been downloaded into our main computer. I'm not exactly sure how it's working, but it's reconfiguring our systems.
How did it get in?
I was able to trace its path from the replicators to our sensor array.
The sensors? They've been scanning that comet for the last eighteen hours...
Those energy readings from the comet's core... the sensor echo... We still don't know what's inside that thing.
Maybe it's time we found out. Could we use the phasers to melt away the outer shell of the comet?
A dispersed wide-field beam might do the trick... it wouldn't take long to come up with the firing parameters... What do you think, Data?
What's the matter?
I believe I recognize these symbols.
How?
I do not know.
Do you think your systems may have been affected?
It is a possibility. I do not believe my systems are currently impaired, but I will run a full self-diagnostic to make certain.
What do these symbols mean?
(continuing, as if reading) "Boundary."
"Border." "Road." "Companion." "Message." "Messenger."
"Death."
Captain, phasers are set for wide dispersal, ten percent maximum power. The beam will terminate automatically when the comet's core is reached.
Very well, Mister Worf. Fire...
Phasers have terminated... the outer shell is gone...
Mister Data... What are we looking at? Is it a ship?
I do not believe so. The object is nearly solid, composed primarily of fortanium and several unknown materials... It is more than eighty-seven million years old.
That's older than the comet itself. Could someone in the D'Arsay system have built it?
There are no technologically advanced cultures in that system now... but perhaps there were eighty-seven million years ago.
But why would anyone hide something like that inside a comet?
It's possible the frozen gasses simply accumulated over time as it travelled through space...
In any case, it's definitely responsible for the system anomalies we've been experiencing. It's been using our sensor beam as a carrier wave to get information into our computers and replicators.
But the question remains: why? What is its purpose?
Captain, I believe this object is an informational archive.
What makes you say that?
I... do not know, sir. However, I seem to have an intuitive understanding of its function.

The internal structure of that thing is pretty complex... and it's got a repetitive node configuration which might suggest a database of some kind... but it could be practically anything. I don't see how you could know for sure what it is.
Data... do you believe you're in communication with that object?
It is a possibility, sir. I recommend that we perform a level one diagnostic of my positronic net immediately to determine if that is the case.
Very well... Mister LaForge, give him a hand.
Do you think it's just trying to make contact with us?

Perhaps. And if this really is an archive from some ancient civilization, we should allow it to do so. But we must be careful... Mister Worf, keep an eye on the sensors. If the Archive poses any danger to the ship, I want you to sever the connection immediately.
Aye, sir.
Come.
Captain...
Come in, Number One...
We've confined the system corruption. It's not spreading any further, but we've still got alien symbols floating around inside our computer...
This is quite a collection you've assembled...
I've seen these things all over the ship. They all look the same... primitive and non-functional.
Ceremonial... and deceptively primitive. Only an advanced technological culture could have built that object out there. These artifacts must have played a ritualistic role in their society.
Do you think Data's right? Have we stumbled across some kind of alien library?
It's possible... and if so, this could be a find of enormous significance. This "library" seems designed to do far more than simply store information. Who knows how much we could learn from it?
I keep seeing this design...
It seems to be a symbol of some significance.
What do you think it means?
The concept of the four cardinal compass directions is common to many different cultures...
The words Data recognized on the computer -- "boundary," "border," "road" -- they were also arranged in that design.
Perhaps everything with the compass design is part of the same theme -- movement. Finding a direction, travelling a path, crossing a boundary--
And "death." One of the symbols was "death."
The ultimate boundary.
I keep seeing this symbol, too.... but it's never prominently displayed...
Always in the background... smaller than the others...
Do you know what it represents?
I have no idea.
Lower synaptic functions are completely normal... Autonomous systems all check out...
I suggest we examine the memory sub-systems next.
All right...
Data... what's the matter?
I am... not certain. I am experiencing a curious sensation...
What is it?
An... impulse.
Impulse? What kind of impulse?
I do not know.
I'm checking your higher functions.
Geordi... What does it feel like when a person... loses his mind?
Data, you're scaring me. What's the matter?
I... do not... know...
You're gonna be all right. You're with me, okay?
Okay.
What's going on... ?
Data...
Masaka is waking.
Captain, he just--
I waited for you, Captain. You should feel honored... I don't usually wait for anybody.
What is it you want?
Masaka is waking.
Are you Masaka?
What were my exact words?
You said, "Masaka is waking."
And isn't that what I've been saying since we first met?
I'm not "Masaka", Captain... I am Ihat.
What have you done to Commander Data?
Commander Data... ?
You mean the one who was here?
Yes.
He's gone. And who can say where?
Counselor Troi, report to Engineering immediately.
Ihat. The place you came from... Is it a cultural archive of your species?
I come from Masaka's city.
Are there others like you there?
There are no others like me.
Who is Masaka?
You will find out...
I don't think Masaka will like this place... at least not the way it is now...
I would like to know more about this Masaka... perhaps we can speak --
Do you understand pain? Death? That is all you need to know about Masaka... that is what she is.
You must go... leave this place before she finds you. It can be done... I did it...
What's going on, sir?
Masaka... ?
Data!
Masaka! I am yours! Every part of me is yours!
(gravely, to N.D. Security) Get him to Sickbay.
Every time he saw Deanna, he'd fall to his knees screaming "Take me, Masaka -- take me."
Data was acting as if he were a sacrificial victim of some kind...
And apparently one all too willing to go to his death.
I put him in isolation in his quarters. He's under guard... he seems to have calmed down a little.
Couldn't we just shut him down and purge his memory systems?
I don't think it's going to be that simple...

This is a micrograph of what's happened to Data's positronic net. As near as I can tell, these are behavioral nodes... I've found fourteen of them so far. I think the Archive is using Data to create different "people" from its culture... in the same way it used our replicators to create artifacts.
As a result, his real personality has been completely buried. In a sense, Data has the android equivalent of multiple personalities.
And the Archive hasn't stopped yet... Data's positronic net is still being transformed. There's no way to tell how many more personalities might emerge...
Our sensors are still in contact with the Archive. Would there be a risk to Data if we severed that connection?

I don't know... but I wouldn't want to take the chance. Right now, our only link to the Archive is that sensor beam. If there's a way to reverse what's happened to Data, I think we're going to need that link to do it.
Mister La Forge, continue to scan the Archive. Try to find some way to access it. In the meantime, I'll see what I can learn from these "people" inside Data.
It's all right... I'm not going to hurt you...
Only Masaka can hurt me... I am for her alone...
I need to speak to Ihat. Do you understand me? Ihat...
Captain...
That was a cruel joke to play on me. For a moment -- a brief moment -- I actually thought that woman was Masaka.
Whoever took your place wasn't afraid of Masaka -- he almost seemed eager for his fate.
Pitiful, isn't it? "Take me! Take me!" Ha. You wouldn't catch me humiliating myself for a woman -- even if she were a queen.
Then Masaka is your queen... ?
She's a lazy creature... she spends most of her time sleeping... The problem is what she does when she's awake.
Then should we try to keep her asleep?
Try to keep the sun from climbing the sky? Only Korgano can do that. And he's not here.
Where is he?
Help me... please...
What's wrong?
I'm afraid.
Of what?
Of her.
Masaka?
Her.
Picard to Bridge! Report!
The Archive just activated some kind of tractor beam, sir. We can't disengage it.
Has there been any damage to the ship?
Nothing major, sir, but Ten Forward reported an emergency. Worf's on his way.
Captain, there's some kind of energy pulse coming through the tractor beam...
It's overriding our control systems...
I'll be right there...
Don't leave me.
I... I... won't... leave you... Please... let go...
Does it hurt?
Yes...
She's going to hurt us all...
Now you've done it. Masaka is awake.
Who is this?
I'd say it's Masaka. Ihat referred to her as a queen... it's not unusual in ceremonial cultures for royalty to be symbolized by a sun.
You said the personalities inside Data were in awe of her... even terrified.
According to Data, the sun image is also the symbol for death.
There it is again... this U-shaped symbol... small and insignificant... almost like an afterthought...
Captain, this is incredible... These artifacts weren't beamed over here from the archive... the matter in Ten Forward was transformed.
Into living plants? How is that possible?
I'm not sure. But bit by bit, the ship's being transformed.
We have received reports from the rest of the ship. Part of deck twelve is now an aqueduct.
What are we being transformed into?
I'm not sure I want to find out.
I don't think we have a choice... we'll have to destroy the Archive. Mister Worf?
Sir, our weapon control systems are inoperative. However, we could configure a photon torpedo for manual launch...
Make it so.
There's so much here we could have learned... I regret losing that opportunity.
Okay... I've locked in the targeting parameters... what's the phase alignment now?
Less than point seven percent.
That'll do it. I'm setting the yield at maximum...
Sir... the onboard power systems are not functioning...
What's going on here... ?
Something tells me we'd better get out of here...
Engineering to Bridge -- emergency transport! Two to beam out...
Maybe we'd better talk in here. The Observation Lounge seems to have become a swamp.
What's our status?
So far the Archive's transformed over twenty percent of the ship... and we've lost main propulsion and weapons systems in the process.
What about communications? Sensors? Life support?
We have communications, and limited sensor control. Life support seems unaffected.
I've been analyzing samples of these alien plant forms. They've been formed from biological matter we have on the ship...
The stone, the artifacts... they're made the same way -- extrapolated from the ship's own alloys.
Apparently the Archive can reorder and transform molecular structures -- including DNA -- to make whatever it wants.
So it's using our ship -- our alloys, our DNA, -- to create elements of its own culture...
But why is all this happening? What is the Archive trying to accomplish?
It could be a weapon.
It is powerful and insidious. It has completely disarmed us.
Maybe it's more benign than that. If a civilization were dying... they might have created this technology to preserve their culture, and re-create it at some later point...
It could even be a sophisticated terraforming device.
The Archive creates an environment... all the elements which enable a culture to exist...
But whatever the intent behind the process, I don't want this ship transformed into an alien city. Mister La Forge, do you have any ideas?

We still haven't been able to cut off that beam... but I've managed to access the Archive by sending an energy pulse back along their signal path. If I can locate the transformation program, I might be able to get control of it.
Good, keep at it...
But somehow... I believe the answer lies there...
... with Masaka. We need to find her... access her... talk to her.
Hello...
It's difficult... to stay warm...
The fire feels good...
But it's not warm enough. Not for an old man.
Tell me... about Masaka.
My daughter?
Yes... how can I talk to her?
Talk -- to Masaka?
Yes. It's important. Can you tell her I must speak with her?
Children grow... forget their parents... no, only Korgano can talk to Masaka.
Korgano... who is that?
So cold... can't stay warm...
Well, you're a persistent one, aren't you?
Ihat?
Is anyone else so charming?
Masaka is taking over my ship.
I told you she would.
I want to talk with her... but I'm told only Korgano can do that.
Who told you that?
An old man... Masaka's father...
Ah, yes... legends say she chopped him up and used his bones to make the world. Any wonder he doesn't like to talk about her?
How can I find Korgano?
I don't know. He's not chasing her anymore.
Where has he gone?
Stop asking these questions. I was fast enough to avoid her once... I don't want her to find me again. I'll end up on her sacrificial slab.
If Masaka is looking for a sacrifice... she can take me instead. Perhaps then she'd stop looking for you.
Well, there's an idea. Better you than me.
All right. Tell me what to do...
You must build Masaka's temple... the Queen's temple. That will get her attention.
Very well. How do I do that?
You need the sign. I could give it to you... so could the Old Man. But just try getting it out of him.
Give me the sign.
If she finds out... You can't imagine her rage... she lets people die of thirst... a terrible death. Sometimes she burns them alive... She is glorious.
Ihat... the sign. What is it?
If she comes... you'll take my place?
Yes.
All right. Quickly. Give me your hand.
A line, as the unending horizon... A curve as --
She has found me.
Masaka, show yourself. I'll go with you...
It seems... I was not fast enough...
So hard to stay warm...
Let me help you...
Are you one of my children? I don't remember anymore.
I need your help. I need the sign for the temple. Masaka's temple.
It won't help you. Korgano no longer pursues her. No one else can stop her.
A line... as the unending horizon... A curve...
A line... as the unending horizon.
... as a rolling hillside.
A point... as a distant bird.
A ray... as the rising sun.
Thank you.
Now sit with me... tend the fire...
I'm alone... there's no one left to help me... she's coming.
Are the others dead? Did Masaka kill them?
No. She sent them away. It will take them days to die.
I think I've found the Archive's transformation program.
Will it accept the symbol for Masaka's temple?
I think so. I've isolated the program's input pathways. They're keyed to accept symbols...
If I input this one, it should initiate the transformation process...
And create the temple?
I hope so... if this is the wrong symbol, it might turn the Enterprise into a big chunk of rock. There's no way to be sure.
The question is... can we trust a personality from an alien Archive that seems bent on taking us over?
Ihat risked his life to show me that symbol... and Masaka killed him for doing it. I think we have to risk it.
Captain. The entire deck has been cleared of personnel. We can proceed.
Commander Riker, we're ready...
Understood. Initiate the transformation.
Aye, sir. I'm inputting the symbol...
Now...
This would seem to be Masaka's temple...
There's no one else here.
Ihat said creating the temple would get her attention... it may take time before she shows herself.
And how will she do that?
I don't know.
Captain... look at this.
This is the first time I've seen these two symbols paired... That could be significant...
There it is again... and again. Clearly this is an important pairing...
"He's not chasing her anymore... "
Sir?
Ihat said that someone named Korgano was not chasing Masaka anymore. And the old man said, "he pursues her no longer... "
In a sense, this smaller symbol is chasing Masaka. Perhaps it represents Korgano.
The symbol suggests antlers of some kind... horns. Maybe it's meant to represent an animal...
Animal gods are worshipped in many cultures...

Both Ihat and the old man said that Korgano was the only one who could control Masaka... Many ritualistic cultures incorporate the idea of "balance" into their belief systems. Masaka is a queen, a powerful, god-like figure... it's not unreasonable to assume that she might have a counterpart... or a consort...
Spread out... see if you can find that horn-like symbol anywhere else.
This is the most prominent instance of the horn symbol we've seen yet...
But now it appears as though Masaka's sun is chasing it.
An animal chasing the sun... ?
Maybe it's simpler than that. Maybe the relationship between them is more like the sun and the moon.
I see... Masaka and Korgano changing positions... the sun setting and the moon rising.
Exactly. Two powerful rulers, changing places in a continuous cycle...
And like the sun and the moon, only one of them can be in ascendance at any given time...
If we could find Korgano within the Archive and bring him out... perhaps he could force Masaka to leave.
But would we be any better off with him?
Ihat and the others didn't seem to be afraid of Korgano...
Masaka...
Masaka, I am Jean-Luc Picard of the Federation--
Go away.
Please listen to us. Your Archive is destroying our ship--
I do not hear you.
She won't even listen to us.
Then we'll have to find someone she will listen to.
I've found it, sir...
This is the only place in the Archive where Korgano's moon symbol is by itself and not paired with Masaka's.
Mister La Forge, access the transformation program.
When you're ready, input the symbol.
Isn't that a little risky?
We have no way of knowing what the result would be. The symbol might generate anything from Korgano's temple... to Korgano himself.
In some sense, Korgano is Masaka's nemesis. Whatever this symbol represents -- it might give us a way to control her. If you have a better idea, I'd be glad to entertain it.
I've accessed the program, sir.
Initiate the transformation.
Another mask...

Perhaps we've been approaching this incorrectly. We're dealing with a highly ritualistic culture... a society based on symbol and myth. Maybe we need to confront them on those terms instead... If I can incorporate myself into their rituals, perhaps Masaka will listen to me.
You're going to pose as Korgano.
Captain, we know so little about this culture... and even less about Korgano himself. How will you convince Masaka that you're him?
I'm not entirely sure. But there are similarities between this culture and others I've studied. I suppose I'll just have to improvise.
Mister Worf, what's our status?
I estimate we have less than two hours before there's nothing left of the ship... at least nothing that we recognize.
Masaka!
Korgano... ?
Are you surprised to see me?
I thought I had escaped you.
You should know that's impossible.
You are a fine hunter... but I am a powerful prey. You will never catch me.
Do you really want to be the prey... forever?
I thought I was alone here. I thought I wouldn't have to share the sky with you...
But without me... you aren't complete. I know you, Masaka... you live for the chase just as much as I do.
Won't you miss being the hunter... pursuing me... forcing me from the sky so that you can rise again?
You know me well, Korgano...
I think you may be getting tired... it's difficult to brighten the sky forever...
I am getting sleepy... you always do that to me...
Only so you can wake at dawn... and begin the hunt again...
Begin the hunt again... I am eager for that.
As am I.
Riker to Picard... I don't know what you did, sir... but it looks like everything's back to normal.
Acknowledged. Mister Data -- are you all right?
I believe so, sir. But I am not entirely certain what has happened. Have I been dreaming again?
I'm afraid it will take some time to explain.
Captain's Log, Stardate 47612.4. Commander La Forge has managed to disable the alien transformation program. Starfleet will send an archaeological team to study the Archive further.
I don't understand... I thought all the alien artifacts had disappeared from the Enterprise.
This was not created by the Archive... this is the clay mask I originally made. I have since glazed it.
Yes. Although I am relieved to be rid of those alien personalities... there is a sense in which I am now... empty.
I can imagine. Doctor Crusher said there might have been dozens of personalities inside you.
I suspect the number was much greater.
My impression is that there were thousands... of all ages and walks of life. It was a remarkable experience.
Well, Data, you may never become fully human... but you've had an experience that transcends the human condition. You have been an entire civilization.
Nonetheless... it's time to stand watch on the night shift.
Yes, sir. Good night.
Get the stasis units in here and bring them on-line. Tell Doctor Selar to use ward three for the ambulatory cases, I'll take the --
Transporter Room Four to Sickbay. They're coming in now.
Acknowledged. Back everyone.
What happened?
The Lenarians attacked us outside the conference room.
He's in cardiac arrest. Get the pulmonary support unit.
Internal hemorrhaging... the bioregulator in his artificial heart's been fused... damage to the spleen and liver... what kind of weapon did this?
A compressed teryon beam.
Forty cc's inoprovaline...
Activity in the isocortex is falling. Cortical stimulator.
Now.
Again.
Welcome to the afterlife, Jean-Luc. You're dead.
What's going on, Q?
I told you. You're dead. This is the afterlife. And I'm God.
You are not God.
Blasphemy! You're lucky I don't cast you out, or smite you or something.
I don't know what game it is you're playing, but I am not going to participate.
What an ego. Did you think the great Jean-Luc Picard would never die?
Q, whatever you've done to --
I haven't done anything. Check your heart rate. Go ahead.
No pulse? What a surprise.
How do I know this isn't another one of your tricks?
Think, Jean-Luc. Why would I go to all the trouble of faking your death when I could simply kill you whenever I felt like it?
Is that what happened?
I wouldn't want to steal the credit... it was a rather disgruntled Lenarian actually.
The conference...
Yes, yes. The conference, the unexpected attack, the compressed teryon beam... the bottom line is, your life ended about five minutes ago under the inept ministrations of Doctor Beverly Crusher.
No. I am not dead. I refuse to believe there is an afterlife which is run by you. The universe is not that badly designed.
Very well. If you really require more evidence of your post-mortem status, I'll just have to provide some...
Jean-Luc...
Father...
I told you not to go running off to that Academy. I told you that Starfleet would bring you to a bad end. But you wouldn't listen. Now look at you... dead before your time.
All right, Q... enough.
Enough what?
Why couldn't you listen? Didn't you understand that I was only looking out for your best interests?
Q, stop this.
Even now, after all these years... you still manage to disappoint me, Jean-Luc.
I hope you're enjoying this, Q.
This isn't for me. This is for you, Jean-Luc... I wanted to give you an opportunity to make peace with your sordid past.
I find it hard to believe that you're doing this for the benefit of my soul.
Now that you've finally shuffled off the mortal coil, we're free to spend some time together. I simply want you to be at peace with yourself.
"Some time together?"... how much time?
Eternity.
So I'm in hell.
That's the spirit, Jean-Luc. Don't let a little thing like death slow down that rapier wit.
Now you're sure you don't have any regrets or feelings of guilt about your former life? I can't have you whining and complaining through eternity.
If I'm truly dead, then my only regret is dying... and finding you here.
